childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1969-1981

You were born the year humans walked on the moon, Woodstock happened, and Sesame Street taught kids that 'one of these things is not like the other.' Richard Nixon had just entered the White House. The Vietnam War was playing on the evening news every night, in color, while your parents ate dinner.

Your childhood was the hangover from the 1960s. The optimism of the Apollo program curdled into the cynicism of Watergate. You were five when Nixon resigned on live television. You probably don't remember it, but your parents do. That moment—a president lying, getting caught, quitting in disgrace—shaped how your entire generation views authority.

You were a latchkey kid before anyone called them that. Both your parents probably worked, or your parents were divorced (the divorce rate doubled during your childhood). You came home to an empty house, let yourself in with the key around your neck, and watched TV until someone got home. Your generation raised itself.

The economy during your childhood was terrible. The 1973 oil crisis happened when you were four. Gas lines, stagflation, the sense that America's best days were behind it. 'Malaise' was the word President Carter used in 1979, and it fit. You grew up in a country that had lost its confidence.

Technology-wise, you were analog all the way. Your family had one phone, attached to a wall. Your TV had maybe five channels and required someone to physically turn a dial. Video games meant Pong, if you were lucky. The future was something that happened in Star Wars, not in your living room.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen X

You're Gen X, born between 1965 and 1980. That's about 65 million people in the US, making you the smallest generation of the 20th century—sandwiched between the massive Boomers and the even more massive Millennials. You've been overlooked your entire life. This is kind of your brand.

Gen X is the 'forgotten generation.' You didn't get a war to define you (Vietnam was your parents', the Gulf War was too short). You didn't get an economic boom (the '70s were miserable, the '80s recovered just in time for you to miss the entry-level jobs). You got cynicism, irony, and a healthy distrust of institutions that promised things and didn't deliver.

Your defining cultural moments were Watergate, the Challenger explosion, and AIDS. Your childhood president resigned in disgrace. Your early adulthood was spent watching friends die of a disease the government refused to acknowledge. You learned early that authority figures lie, institutions fail, and you'd better figure things out yourself.

The term 'Gen X' comes from Douglas Coupland's 1991 novel about overeducated, underemployed twentysomethings working 'McJobs.' That was you. That's still kind of you. You entered the workforce during the recession of the early '90s and learned that the promises your Boomer parents made about working hard and getting ahead were mostly fiction.

You're the generation that perfected sarcasm as a defense mechanism. You're suspicious of sincerity, allergic to enthusiasm, and deeply uncomfortable with the ways younger generations earnestly care about things. You invented indie rock and grunge because mainstream culture felt fake. You still think it does.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year Midnight Cowboy won Best Picture—the first and only X-rated film to do so. Easy Rider was in theaters. Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid redefined the buddy movie. The summer of '69 wasn't just a Bryan Adams song; it was the actual summer you were born, complete with moon landings and Woodstock mud.

Musically, 1969 was the peak and the end of the '60s dream. Woodstock happened in August. The Beatles released Abbey Road. The Rolling Stones played Altamont in December, where someone got stabbed to death in front of the stage. The '60s didn't fade out—they crashed and burned.

Your childhood was The Brady Bunch, Scooby-Doo, and Saturday morning cartoons that existed primarily to sell you sugary cereal. Your teenage years belonged to MTV, which launched when you were twelve. You remember when music videos were new, when 'Video Killed the Radio Star' meant something, when MTV actually played music.

You came of age with John Hughes movies. The Breakfast Club, Sixteen Candles, Ferris Bueller's Day Off—these weren't just films, they were field guides to suburban adolescence. Hughes understood that high school felt like life or death, even if it wasn't. You probably still have opinions about which character you were.

Your music was punk, then new wave, then alternative, then grunge. You went from the Ramones to Talking Heads to R.E.M. to Nirvana. You watched Kurt Cobain die and knew something had ended. The commercialization of grunge proved what you'd always suspected: nothing authentic stays authentic for long.

You were the last generation to grow up without the internet. Your pop culture was shared—everyone watched the same shows, listened to the same radio stations, saw the same movies. There was a monoculture, even if you hated most of it. That shared experience is gone now, and you're not sure whether to mourn it or celebrate.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year ARPANET was created—the military research network that would eventually become the internet. You were six months old when the first message was sent between computers at UCLA and Stanford. The internet is literally as old as you are, but you didn't know it existed until you were in your twenties.

Your childhood technology was analog and mechanical. Rotary phones. Manual typewriters. Slide rules if your parents were engineers. Calculators were expensive, bulky, and banned in schools because they'd make you lazy at math. The most sophisticated technology in your house was probably the microwave.

You were eleven when the Apple II came out. You were fifteen when the IBM PC launched. You were twenty-two when the World Wide Web went public. You watched the entire digital revolution happen in real-time, but you weren't born into it. You're digital immigrants who learned the language as adults.

This gives you a unique perspective. You remember what it was like before. You can use technology, but you're not dependent on it the way younger generations are. You survived decades without smartphones, GPS, or Google. You can still read a map, look things up in actual books, and entertain yourself without a screen.

You were thirty when Google launched. Thirty-five when Facebook opened to the public. Thirty-eight when the iPhone dropped. By then, you had careers, families, established lives. Social media didn't define your adolescence—it invaded your adulthood. You adopted it reluctantly, skeptically, and you still think it's mostly terrible.

Your generation created much of this technology—Gen Xers founded Google, Amazon, and SpaceX—but you also remember the promises that were made and broken. The internet was supposed to democratize information and bring people together. It did those things, sort of, while also making everything worse in ways nobody predicted.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were two months old when Neil Armstrong walked on the moon. You don't remember it, but your parents never let you forget it. The moon landing was supposed to be the beginning of a space-faring future. Instead, it was pretty much the peak. Humans haven't been back since 1972, and you're still waiting for your jetpack.

You were five when Watergate ended Nixon's presidency. Your generation's defining political lesson: they're all crooks, and the only difference is whether they get caught. This cynicism has served you well. You were right to not trust institutions. They've spent your entire life proving you right.

You were ten during the Iranian hostage crisis, which dragged on for 444 days and made America look impotent. You were eleven when Reagan was shot. You were twelve when John Lennon was murdered. The early '80s felt dangerous, volatile, like the country was coming apart.

You were seventeen when the Challenger exploded. You probably watched it live in your classroom—NASA had made a big deal about the teacher-astronaut program. Seven people died on television while you watched. Another lesson: technology fails, heroes die, and watching something live doesn't make it less random or cruel.

You were twenty when the Berlin Wall fell. Twenty-two when the Soviet Union collapsed. The Cold War you'd grown up fearing ended not with nuclear annihilation but with people chipping at concrete with hammers. It felt like the end of history. It wasn't—history was just catching its breath.

You were thirty-two on 9/11. Old enough to have a career, maybe kids. You watched the towers fall and knew the world had shifted again. The forever wars that followed—Afghanistan, Iraq—were fought by people younger than you. You were too old to deploy, too young to retire, stuck watching another generation get sent to die in places they couldn't find on a map.

You were thirty-nine during the 2008 financial crisis. Unlike the Millennials who graduated into it, you had something to lose. You watched your 401(k) crater, your house value plummet, your job security evaporate. You'd played by the rules, and the rules had changed without warning.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce in the late '80s or early '90s, depending on whether you went to college. The economy was unstable—recession in 1990-91, recovery that felt sluggish, jobs that paid less than your parents' jobs had. The term 'McJob' was invented for you: low-pay, low-prestige, low-dignity work in the service economy.

Your generation invented the concept of 'slacking'—not because you were lazy, but because working hard didn't seem to lead anywhere. The corporate ladder your parents climbed had rungs missing. Promotions were rare. Loyalty was one-sided. Companies would lay you off the moment it helped their quarterly numbers, so why would you sacrifice your life for them?

You're the generation that normalized job-hopping, not out of disloyalty but survival. You learned that the only way to get a raise was to leave. You learned that companies don't care about you, so you shouldn't care about them. This was called being 'cynical' by Boomers who'd had the same job for thirty years. You called it realistic.

The dot-com boom of the late '90s was your first real economic break. You were in your late twenties, early thirties—old enough to benefit, young enough to pivot. Some of you got rich. Most of you got experience that would be useful later. Then the bubble burst in 2000, and you learned another lesson: booms end, and timing is mostly luck.

By the time the 2008 crisis hit, you were mid-career. You had more to lose than the kids just entering the workforce, and you lost plenty. But you'd also been through recessions before. You knew how to survive. You're the generation that expects the worst and plans accordingly. This is depressing, but it works.

You're now in leadership positions, but you manage differently than Boomers did. You're more hands-off, more skeptical of corporate BS, more likely to tell your employees to take time off and mean it. You remember what it was like to be exploited, and you try not to pass it on. Try.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You're the generation that dated without apps, married later than your parents, and divorced at higher rates than anyone before or since. The divorce rate peaked when you were kids, which meant many of you grew up in broken homes. This shaped how you approached relationships: cautiously, skeptically, with escape routes planned.

You met people in person—at bars, through friends, at work, in the increasingly rare 'third places' that weren't home or office. You called them on phones attached to walls and made plans you couldn't change at the last minute. If someone stood you up, you just stood there, waiting, wondering. There was no texting 'running late.'

Your generation delayed marriage compared to your parents. Some of this was economic—you couldn't afford it. Some was cultural—you'd seen too many bad marriages end badly. You were the first generation to really normalize living together before marriage, which scandalized your parents but made sense to you. Why buy before you try?

Communication evolved dramatically during your adult life. You went from landlines to cell phones to smartphones. From letters to email to texting to WhatsApp. You've adapted to each new platform, but you remember what it was like before instant communication was possible. You appreciate the silence that younger people find unbearable.

You're not as online as Millennials or Gen Z. Social media entered your life in your thirties, after your identity was already formed. You use it, but it doesn't use you. You can put the phone down. You remember what it was like to be unreachable, and sometimes you miss it.

Your friendships are smaller, deeper, and more resilient than the hundreds of 'friends' younger generations accumulate online. You have people you've known for forty years, people who remember who you were before life got complicated. That continuity matters more as you age.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You grew up during stagflation—high inflation, high unemployment, gas lines, malaise. Your first economic memories are of scarcity and anxiety. This shaped a financial psychology based on expecting the worst. You're savers, hoarders of resources, deeply suspicious that the good times won't last. They usually don't.

Your relationship with money is pragmatic. You don't expect windfalls. You don't believe in get-rich-quick schemes. You invest conservatively, save obsessively, and still feel like it's not enough. The promise of retirement—that you'd work for forty years and then relax—seems increasingly fictional.

You've been through three major recessions as an adult: the early '90s, the dot-com bust, and 2008. Each one taught you that economic security is an illusion. Jobs disappear. Markets crash. The safety nets have holes. You've learned to be your own safety net, which is exhausting but necessary.

Housing was supposed to be the path to wealth. For some of you, it worked—you bought in the '90s or early 2000s before prices exploded. For others, 2008 destroyed everything. You watched your home value collapse, maybe lost the house entirely. The idea that real estate always goes up turned out to be another lie.

You're financially better off than Millennials, mostly because of timing. You entered the workforce when things were bad, but not catastrophic. You had time to accumulate assets before the ladder got pulled up. This doesn't make you rich—it just makes you slightly less screwed than the generations behind you.

Your financial anxiety is compounded by having aging parents and adult children who both might need your support. You're the sandwich generation, caught between caring for people older than you and helping people younger than you, while trying to fund a retirement that keeps getting pushed further into the future.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your generation's superpower—self-reliance—is also your Achilles' heel. You're so used to figuring things out yourself that you don't ask for help when you need it. You suffer in silence, dismiss your own struggles, tell yourself to toughen up. This served you well in a world that didn't offer support. It's less useful now that support exists.

You're deeply uncomfortable with earnestness. Irony and sarcasm are your native languages, and you use them to deflect anything that feels too real. This makes you seem cool and detached, but it also makes it hard to connect deeply, advocate for yourself, or admit when something matters. You've been performing not-caring for so long you sometimes forget you actually do care.

You missed the diversity training. Your formative years were less diverse than what came after, and the language around identity, gender, and race has evolved faster than some of you have. You're not bigots—mostly—but you sometimes stumble over terminology that didn't exist when you were learning how to talk about people. This frustrates younger people, and learning feels harder than it should.

You have a chip on your shoulder about being forgotten. Stuck between Boomers and Millennials, you've spent decades being ignored by marketers, politicians, and trend pieces. This has made you prickly about recognition, dismissive of generations that get more attention, and sometimes bitter about doing the work while others get the credit.

You're technologically capable but not always current. You can use smartphones and social media, but you're often a few years behind the latest platforms. This isn't inability—it's choice. But it means you sometimes miss cultural moments that happen online, and you're increasingly out of touch with how younger people communicate.

Your cynicism, while often justified, can become self-defeating. You expect things to fail, so you don't try. You expect institutions to disappoint, so you don't engage with them. The world needs fixing, but your generation is more likely to mock the problems than organize to solve them. Ironic detachment isn't a political strategy.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1989-1999): You entered adulthood during economic uncertainty and found your footing during the longest peacetime expansion in American history. The '90s were your decade—you were young enough to enjoy them, old enough to participate. Grunge, the internet boom, Clinton-era optimism (such as it was). You probably had some fun before everything got serious. You started careers, maybe got married, figured out who you were outside your parents' house.

Your 30s (1999-2009): The decade that broke everything. You were thirty when 9/11 happened. The wars that followed, the security state, the paranoia—all of it landed on you in your early thirties. Then the 2008 crash hit when you were thirty-nine. You had mortgages, kids, responsibilities. You watched your wealth evaporate and spent years clawing it back. This decade aged you in ways that don't show on the outside.

Your 40s (2009-2019): Recovery, rebuilding, middle age. You focused on stability—keeping jobs, maintaining relationships, raising kids who didn't seem to need the same things you'd needed. You watched smartphones take over the world and social media change how people relate to each other. You adapted, but you also held back, suspicious of how much technology wanted to consume. This was supposed to be your peak decade. It felt more like survival.

Your 50s (2019-2029): You're here now, or approaching it. COVID hit when you were fifty or fifty-one. Another crisis, another adaptation. Your kids are grown or nearly grown. Your parents are aging, maybe dying. You're thinking about what comes next—retirement, legacy, meaning. You've spent thirty years working. The finish line is visible, but the path to it keeps changing. You're tired in ways you didn't expect, but you're also more comfortable in your skin than you've ever been.

Your 60s and beyond (2029+): Retirement is the theory. The practice depends on whether you can afford it, whether Social Security still exists, whether healthcare costs don't bankrupt you. You've seen enough to know predictions are worthless. The future isn't the gleaming space colony you were promised as a kid. It's messy, uncertain, and probably warmer than it should be. But you've survived everything so far. You'll probably survive this too. Probably.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.6 million people born in 1969. The entire Gen X generation is about 65 million people in the US, making you the smallest generation of the 20th century. This has shaped everything—you've been overlooked by marketers, ignored by politicians, and chronically underestimated.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), you're smaller, quieter, and more skeptical. Boomers inherited a booming postwar economy, cheap housing, and employer-funded pensions. You inherited stagflation, Watergate, and the end of the American Dream. Boomers got free love and idealism. You got AIDS and cynicism. They got Woodstock; you got the hangover.

But you're also more adaptable than Boomers. You've navigated more economic crises, technological revolutions, and social upheavals. You didn't expect the world to be fair, so you planned accordingly. You're the generation that learned to pivot, hustle, and survive without the safety nets Boomers took for granted.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're more financially stable but less optimistic. You bought houses when they were affordable. You paid off student loans before they became life sentences. You got into the job market before it became a hunger game. This makes Millennials resent you sometimes, which is fair—you had advantages they didn't, even if you didn't feel advantaged at the time.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're practically analog. You remember a world without internet, smartphones, or social media. You can disconnect in ways they find incomprehensible. You're bemused by their anxiety, impressed by their activism, and occasionally horrified by their TikTok dances. You're old enough to be their parents, which many of you are.

Your life expectancy is around 78-80 years, which means you've got two to three decades left, statistically speaking. You're healthier than previous generations at this age—better medicine, less smoking, more kale—but you're also more stressed, more medicated, and more worried about climate change making the last decades of your life interesting in the wrong ways.

Your generation's lasting contribution might be pragmatism. You didn't change the world like Boomers claimed to. You didn't break the internet like Millennials did. You just kept showing up, doing the work, expecting nothing, and being pleasantly surprised when things occasionally worked out. That's not nothing. That's survival.

year_events: Stonewall riots launched LGBTQ rights movement
